posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
I feel it is extremely beneficial for Signal to find opportunities to get ahead of others.

I‚Äôm suggesting there be a message type that is editable by everyone in a group chat or 1:1 chat. This would be useful for making lists. Right now some of my group chats get clogged with repeated messages where people are adding things to participation lists and such.

I really feel this is something where Signal can get ahead of the rest.

This paired with a pinned message in a group would actually be amazing.

  • Points if the creator of the editable message can also roll it back to a previous state if something goes wrong.

link_counts.title: Send a message editable by everyone

posts.name: Fabian
posts.cooked: Maybe also an Option if everyone can edit the message in a group or only someone who is an admin for this specific group. This could be useful to communicate in teams with different roles etc.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Similar, possibly a dupe:

Secure List between contacts Feature Requests
I would find it super useful to be able to keep a list with each contact/group. Instead of adding more and more fluff like giant emoticons this would actually be useful. It could be used to keep a grocery list, list of money owed, planning items in groups, being able to pin messages to it etc.

While this is a nice suggestion, I think this essentially is asking for creating a document collaboration tool within signal. In my mind that would be stretching the basic function of an IM tool too far‚Ä¶ From a technical perspective, maintaining concurrency when multiple people are allowed to edit a message is going to be big challenge, given signal doesn‚Äôt keep a copy of the message in a central repository, so that, whoever edits can acquire a lock or something of that kind to maintain sanity. When multiple people start editing a message and send them out this will quickly become a nightmare with some edits overwriting others etc‚Ä¶

posts.name: Fabian
posts.cooked:
This is indeed a good thought. Without being able to lock the message it is unlikely this will ever be implemented I guess because the chance for possible errors or unwanted behavior is just too big.
Maybe the community comes up with a solution for this issue.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
It‚Äôs not. The confine is editing a list inside of an edited message. The only necessary client side change is accepting message edits from other users.

This also covers a really common use case in messaging, especially in group chats. Unless you‚Äôre suggesting people use word documents to collaborate whether they‚Äôre going to a football match or not

If you personally would want something more advanced, you‚Äôve gone outside of the scope of my request.

posts.name: Fabian
posts.cooked:
I get what you want, but what happens if two people edit a message at the same time?
I am pretty sure this will cause problems if it is not handled properly which means it will most likely not be implemented.
I am also not sure if you could display that someone is currently editing the message because in my understanding this wouldn‚Äôt happen on the server until the editing users sents the message

I‚Äôd say that‚Äôs functionality not meant for a chat app. Pinned messages would be an absolute requirement for this to even be remotely useful, otherwise the message is just lost to history.

But then you have issues with multiple edits being made at the same time and having to try to keep things in sync.

Also, what happens if someone edits a message that you have deleted locally? The client could easily ignore it, but then you might unintentionally miss important information. The client could restore it, but then you‚Äôd need an option to ignore edits to deleted messages so people can remove things they don‚Äôt care about; however, that would require keeping some sort of history of deleted messages so the client can remember which ones you wanted updates from‚Ä¶

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Multiple edits are not an issue. You keep the one with the latest timestamp, that‚Äôs just how edited messages work even now.

Multiple edits by multiple users and around the same time are an issue and not something that currently happens. The scenario is this: you start editing ‚Äúversion 1‚Äù of the message, and at the same time someone else starts editing, also on ‚Äúversion 1‚Äù. Both of you have made substantial edits and hit ‚Äúsend/save/whatever‚Äù to send your changes. If the latest timestamp is what ‚Äúwins‚Äù then whichever edit came through first gets dropped. It might be there in the edit history, but that‚Äôs useless and most people won‚Äôt see it ‚Äì you want the changes to be in the actual message. So now that user has to go back and edit again and hope that no one else edits in the meantime. In a busy group that can make it impossible to edit anything and makes it very easy to troll.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
Multiple users is not a more complex situation. It‚Äôs going to be handled the same way Signal currently handles clashes when multiple clients are editing a message right now.

Trolling is a human issue and is handled humanly like it is right now (blocking, removing from groups, etc). This is a behavioral issue, and Signal is built for more causal users and not public groups. This is well within scope.

Whatnoww:

It‚Äôs going to be handled the same way Signal currently handles clashes when multiple clients are editing a message right now

You‚Äôre entirely missing the point. This situation is not handled currently, at least not in a way that is friendly to multiple users. What you are describing is a single user editing the same message on multiple devices which, aside from being a weird use case, is one that the user would be aware of, so if they run into issues it‚Äôs their own fault. In the case of multiple users editing the same message, if Signal just accepts edits in the order that they arrive as it seemingly does now, you have major revision issues and a very unpleasant user experience. It‚Äôs not a behavior issue; you don‚Äôt even have to try to disrupt someone‚Äôs edits, it will just happen.

The way Signal handles edits now does not work with multiple simultaneous edits because the second edit will effectively be as if the user fully reverted the previous edit, then applied their own edits.

As a possible workaround the group description could be used for things like this.
Depending on the settings it can be editable by everyone or only by the admin of the group.

Each time someone edits the group description a message is shown in the chat (screenshot from Signal Desktop):

Nothing is merged automatically if multiple members of the group change the group description at the same time. But there is a message in the group chat for each edit and a click on ‚ÄúView‚Äù shows the content of each edit. So no info is lost and you can merge the changes manually.

Nice suggestion. How will it be different from Reply feature from which you can see whole conversation about such message provided all the participants use this one
In other messaging apps Reply feature is available but we can only trace back to last message to which we sent a reply.

Each reply is going to show you only a few lines from the last reply. However if everyone uses the reply then you can use the bubble next to replied messages to trace the conversation. But it can work only if everyone uses reply instead of just adding their messages and in large groups, it can become just unmanageable to trace large number of responses. But, for short conversations this could work.
What you are suggesting is similar to tracking changes in Office applications especially Word processors and spreadsheets. Did I get this right
I thought that‚Äôs what you were suggesting‚Ä¶ yes, if everyone uses reply, you can track the whole chain already‚Ä¶ so that can be a workaround.

I‚Äôd like to be able to collaborate with another person or all other people in a group within a single message.

For example, I want to send my wife a message right now that says

Things to do this weekend:

  • install ceiling fan
  • mow lawn
  • wash siding
  • water plants

But I want her to be able to add to the list after I send it. So I‚Äôd like to set the permission so that she can edit it. Or, more simply, set it so that ‚Äúeveryone else in the group‚Äù can edit and leave it at that. I‚Äôd imagine if this feature is popular a later iteration of it can be ‚Äúallow group admins to edit‚Äù or even individuals in the group.

As a workaround you could create a group, allow all members to edit the description and collaborate there. A little weird, but it‚Äôs an option I‚Äôve used before. :)

I agree it would be nice, but there have already been some discussions on admin editing/deleting so that probably won‚Äôt happen. This request however doesn‚Äôt seem as controversial to me, so maybe they could consider it. Would probably require some work though‚Ä¶
How do you handle multiple people editing the group description at the same time?
